metadata.case_name: Appellant Firm v. Dominion of India & Darjeeling Himalayan Railway Co.

facts.text: 259 bales of cloth delivered on May 10, 1946, at Wadi Bunder station on the Great Indian Peninsula Railway (G.I.P. Railway) to be carried to Giellekhola station on the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway (D.H. Railway) via G.I.P. Railway, East Indian Railway (E.I. Railway), Bengal Assam Railway (B.A. Railway), and D.H. Railway.
169 bales delivered to the appellant on June 7, 1946, to whom the Railway Receipt had been endorsed.
Remaining 90 bales traced in about September 1946 at Gadkhali station on the B.A. Railway.
90 bales arrived at Giellekhola shortly prior to December 21, 1946, in a very damaged condition; appellant requested open delivery on December 21, 1946.
Open delivery of the contents of the 90 bales given to the appellant on February 12, 1947; damage assessed by agreement between appellant, B.A. Railway, and D.H. Railway at Rs. 27,920-13-6.
Notice under s. 80 CPC sent on January 29, 1948, to Secretary of Railway Department, Government of India, demanding Rs. 34,192.
Suit filed on April 9, 1948, for damages.
Trial Court (Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling) decreed suit against D.H. Railway only for Rs. 27,920-13-6 on March 15, 1956; dismissed against Dominion of India.
D.H. Railway appealed to Calcutta High Court; appellant filed cross-objection; High Court allowed appeal, dismissed cross-objection.
D.H. Railway went into liquidation; liquidators brought on record.
Appellant sent telegram on July 1, 1946, and letter on July 9, 1946, to General Manager, D.H. Railway, about 90 bales not reaching destination.
Letter dated December 21, 1946, from appellant stating consignment arrived at Giellekhola in very damaged condition.
Claim letter dated June 26, 1947, by advocate for Rs. 34,192 to B.A. Railway, D.H. Railway, etc.; repudiated by G.I.P. Railway.

legal_issues.text: Whether notice under s. 77 of the Railways Act, 1890, was given within six months of delivery of goods to the railway.
Whether the suit is barred by limitation under Art. 30 of the Limitation Act.
Whether damage occurred on the D.H. Railway system.
Which Limitation Act article applies: Art. 30 or Art. 31.

petitioner_arguments.text: Telegram and letter of July 1 and 9, 1946, to D.H. Railway amount to compliance with s. 77 Railways Act.
Limitation starts from date of discovery of damage or open delivery (Feb 12, 1947); suit within time under Art. 30 Limitation Act.
Impossible to give notice u/s 77 within 6 months as damage not known till later.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 77 Railways Act; maxim lex non cogit ad impossibilia

petitioner_arguments.text: Damage occurred prior to receipt at Giellekhola; decree should be against all railways.

respondent_arguments.text: No notice u/s 77 given to any railway within 6 months; letters only requested tracing and delivery, not claim for compensation.
Suit barred by limitation; damage occurred before Dec 21, 1946, suit filed April 9, 1948.
Consignment received from B.A. Railway in same condition; damage not on D.H. Railway.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J.: Damage occurred prior to Dec 21, 1946, based on plaint and letters; suit barred by Art. 30 Limitation Act. No notice u/s 77 as letters only sought tracing, not compensation claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Knowledge irrelevant for s.77; claim must be preferred within 6 months regardless.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J.: Letters do not comply with s.77; object is to prevent stale claims.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Request to trace goods not a claim for compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Mudholkar J. (majority): Letter July 9, 1946, implies claim for compensation under s.77 for D.H. Railway; liberally construed to satisfy object of enabling enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim implied where consignment not delivered as per contract.

court_reasoning.text: No notice to GIP, EI, BA Railways; suit dismissed against them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice required to each railway sued.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 30 applies (injury to goods), not Art. 31; burden on railway to prove damage >1 year before suit; not discharged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant knew of external damage Dec 1946, but internal damage assessed Feb 1947; no evidence when occurred.

court_reasoning.text: Burden shifts to delivering railway (D.H.) to show damage not on its system; no evidence led, presumption not rebutted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Damaged condition on delivery raises presumption.

holdings.text: Notice u/s 77 complied for D.H. Railway via July 9, 1946 letter implying compensation claim.
No notice to other railways; suit dismissed against them.
Suit not barred by limitation under Art. 30; D.H. Railway failed to prove damage occurred >1 year before suit.
Damage presumed on D.H. Railway as delivering railway; no evidence to rebut.

precedents_cited.case_name: Governor-General in Council v. Musaddi Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of s.77 is to prevent stale claims.

precedents_cited.case_name: Salem Dayal Bagh Stores Ltd. v. The Governor General in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Letter asking enquiries not notice u/s 77.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mardab Ali v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Letter requesting location not notice u/s 77; must demand compensation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Amar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on railway to prove when loss/injury occurred for limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shamsul Huq v. Secretary of State
Mahadeva Ayyar v. S.I. Railway Co.
Governor-General in Council v. G.S. Mills Ltd.
Meghaji Hirajee Co. v. B.N. Railway Co.

statutes_cited.name: Railways Act, 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory notice for compensation within 6 months; burden for other railways.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: 1 year from injury for suit; Art. 30 applies to injury, not non-delivery.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice before suit against government; time excluded for limitation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part by majority; High Court decree set aside insofar as D.H. Railway concerned; trial court decree for Rs. 27,920-13-6 against D.H. Railway restored. Suit dismissed against other railways. Appellant entitled to proportionate costs against D.H. Railway.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for Rs. 27,920-13-6 against D.H. Railway (liquidators).
outcome.costs: Appellant entitled to proportionate costs against D.H. Railway.

key_quotes.text: "A request to trace goods and expedite their delivery is certainly not a claim to compensation in respect of them."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Where a person says that his consignment has not been delivered as it should have been delivered according to the contract between him and the railway administration he must be regarded as making it clear that he would be holding the railway administration to its contractual engagement which necessarily involves the payment of damages."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mudholkar J. holding letter implies s.77 claim.

key_quotes.text: "The burden would be on the railway administration who want to non-suit the plaintiff on the ground of limitation to establish that the loss or injury occurred more than a year before the institution of the suit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Union of India v. Amar Singh, applied to limitation.
